Front-End/Full-Stack C# Mobile Developer (Part Time / Full time)Location: Remote — Dallas–Fort Worth metro preferred (flexible)Commitment: Immediate start • Part‑Time with path to Full‑TimeCompensation: Milestone‑based payments plus equity that vests after a waiting periodTRANSPARENCY NOTE• Payment – For each agreed milestone (e.g., “Deliver Feature X”) we jointly define deliverables, target hours, delivery date, and a fixed payment amount. Payment is released as soon as the milestone is accepted.• Equity – You will receive a founding‑engineer equity grant (combination of tokens and company shares) that vests according to a standard cliff and schedule. Equity becomes yours only after the vesting period.If an outcome‑based, ownership‑heavy model excites you, read on.WHAT YOU’LL DO• Own the MVP mobile app end‑to‑end: architecture, coding, testing, deployment, and iteration.• Implement UI/UX designs provided by our designer through Figma.• Ship fast in .NET 8/9 C# using MAUI Hybrid, Blazor, and WebAssembly for a single codebase across mobile and web.• Drive frontend excellence—pixel‑perfect, intuitive, performant experiences are priority #1.• Contribute to lightweight backend APIs (auth, data models, CI/CD hooks) when needed.• Set up the pipeline: automated builds, test harnesses, and App Store / Play Store releases.• Influence product direction directly with the founders—your voice matters.• Help establish engineering best practices: coding standards, code review culture, branching strategy, and a “you build it, you own it” ops mindset.MUST‑HAVE SKILLS & EXPERIENCE• .NET 8/9 and C# — expert, production‑grade code• MAUI Hybrid & Blazor (WASM) — built at least one cross‑platform mobile app through launch• Modern frontend craft — responsive UI, accessibility, offline‑first patterns• RESTful APIs & JSON — consumption and lightweight authoring• Source control with Git/GitHub — branch strategy, pull‑request reviews, actions/workflows• Startup execution — comfort with ambiguity, bias toward action, radical ownershipNICE‑TO‑HAVE EXTRAS• Azure serverless, especially AKS and Key Vault• Figma‑based UI/UX implementation experience• Containers & orchestration: Docker, Kubernetes/AKS, Helm charts• MongoDB schema design and tuning• Automated testing with xUnit• CI/CD using GitHub Actions or Azure PipelinesREADY TO BUILD SOMETHING THAT MATTERS?Email careers@newbitcoin.app with:• Resume or/and a brief note on why our stack and mission excite you.• Links to apps you shipped (GitHub or store listings).We respect your time: please apply only if a milestone‑based payments model plus later‑vesting equity fits your situation. 🧵Part 8 of my microservices project(BookLending System)Just wrapped up the Reminder Service in my Book Lending microservices project.It listens for a BookLent event, and schedules an email reminder 3 days before the due date using Hangfire. No missed deadlines. No angry librarians. 📚🔔 How it works:1.  When a book is lent (via the Lending Service),2.  BookLent event is fired into RabbitMQ.3.  The Reminder Service listens for it, and with Hangfire, schedules a reminder email 3 days before the book is due.4. The actual email? That’s handled cleanly by the Notification Service, keeping responsibilities separate.What's Next?I'm diving into some refactoring, but not just any refactoring.I'll be implementing the Outbox Pattern for:- User Registration Emails- Lending Reminder EmailsWhy? Because I want guaranteed delivery.With the Outbox Pattern, events are stored in the same transaction as the main data. Then a background worker reliably publishes them to RabbitMQ.GitHub Repo: https://lnkd.in/dMmSNCWNPrevious Post: https://lnkd.in/dHHkeqJj hashtag#csharp hashtag#dotnet hashtag#microservices hashtag#massTransit hashtag#Hangfire hashtag#outboxpattern hashtag#distributedSystems hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#backenddevelopment hashtag#hiring

🧵Part 8 of my microservices project(BookLending System)Just wrapped up the Reminder Service in my Book Lending microservices project.It listens for a BookLent event, and schedules an email reminder 3 days before the due date using Hangfire. No missed deadlines. No angry librarians. 📚🔔 How it works:1.  When a book is lent (via the Lending Service),2.  BookLent event is fired into RabbitMQ.3.  The Reminder Service listens for it, and with Hangfire, schedules a reminder email 3 days before the book is due.4. The actual email? That’s handled cleanly by the Notification Service, keeping responsibilities separate.What's Next?I'm diving into some refactoring, but not just any refactoring.I'll be implementing the Outbox Pattern for:- User Registration Emails- Lending Reminder EmailsWhy? Because I want guaranteed delivery.With the Outbox Pattern, events are stored in the same transaction as the main data. Then a background worker reliably publishes them to RabbitMQ.GitHub Repo: https://lnkd.in/dMmSNCWNPrevious Post: https://lnkd.in/dHHkeqJj hashtag#csharp hashtag#dotnet hashtag#microservices hashtag#massTransit hashtag#Hangfire hashtag#outboxpattern hashtag#distributedSystems hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#backenddevelopment hashtag#hiring

🧵Part 8 of my microservices project(BookLending System)Just wrapped up the Reminder Service in my Book Lending microservices project.It listens for a BookLent event, and schedules an email reminder 3 days before the due date using Hangfire. No missed deadlines. No angry librarians. 📚🔔 How it works:1.  When a book is lent (via the Lending Service),2.  BookLent event is fired into RabbitMQ.3.  The Reminder Service listens for it, and with Hangfire, schedules a reminder email 3 days before the book is due.4. The actual email? That’s handled cleanly by the Notification Service, keeping responsibilities separate.What's Next?I'm diving into some refactoring, but not just any refactoring.I'll be implementing the Outbox Pattern for:- User Registration Emails- Lending Reminder EmailsWhy? Because I want guaranteed delivery.With the Outbox Pattern, events are stored in the same transaction as the main data. Then a background worker reliably publishes them to RabbitMQ.GitHub Repo: https://lnkd.in/dMmSNCWNPrevious Post: https://lnkd.in/dHHkeqJj hashtag#csharp hashtag#dotnet hashtag#microservices hashtag#massTransit hashtag#Hangfire hashtag#outboxpattern hashtag#distributedSystems hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#backenddevelopment hashtag#hiring

🧵Part 8 of my microservices project(BookLending System)Just wrapped up the Reminder Service in my Book Lending microservices project.It listens for a BookLent event, and schedules an email reminder 3 days before the due date using Hangfire. No missed deadlines. No angry librarians. 📚🔔 How it works:1.  When a book is lent (via the Lending Service),2.  BookLent event is fired into RabbitMQ.3.  The Reminder Service listens for it, and with Hangfire, schedules a reminder email 3 days before the book is due.4. The actual email? That’s handled cleanly by the Notification Service, keeping responsibilities separate.What's Next?I'm diving into some refactoring, but not just any refactoring.I'll be implementing the Outbox Pattern for:- User Registration Emails- Lending Reminder EmailsWhy? Because I want guaranteed delivery.With the Outbox Pattern, events are stored in the same transaction as the main data. Then a background worker reliably publishes them to RabbitMQ.GitHub Repo: https://lnkd.in/dMmSNCWNPrevious Post: https://lnkd.in/dHHkeqJj hashtag#csharp hashtag#dotnet hashtag#microservices hashtag#massTransit hashtag#Hangfire hashtag#outboxpattern hashtag#distributedSystems hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#backenddevelopment hashtag#hiring

🧵Part 8 of my microservices project(BookLending System)Just wrapped up the Reminder Service in my Book Lending microservices project.It listens for a BookLent event, and schedules an email reminder 3 days before the due date using Hangfire. No missed deadlines. No angry librarians. 📚🔔 How it works:1.  When a book is lent (via the Lending Service),2.  BookLent event is fired into RabbitMQ.3.  The Reminder Service listens for it, and with Hangfire, schedules a reminder email 3 days before the book is due.4. The actual email? That’s handled cleanly by the Notification Service, keeping responsibilities separate.What's Next?I'm diving into some refactoring, but not just any refactoring.I'll be implementing the Outbox Pattern for:- User Registration Emails- Lending Reminder EmailsWhy? Because I want guaranteed delivery.With the Outbox Pattern, events are stored in the same transaction as the main data. Then a background worker reliably publishes them to RabbitMQ.GitHub Repo: https://lnkd.in/dMmSNCWNPrevious Post: https://lnkd.in/dHHkeqJj hashtag#csharp hashtag#dotnet hashtag#microservices hashtag#massTransit hashtag#Hangfire hashtag#outboxpattern hashtag#distributedSystems hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#backenddevelopment hashtag#hiring

🧵Part 8 of my microservices project(BookLending System)Just wrapped up the Reminder Service in my Book Lending microservices project.It listens for a BookLent event, and schedules an email reminder 3 days before the due date using Hangfire. No missed deadlines. No angry librarians. 📚🔔 How it works:1.  When a book is lent (via the Lending Service),2.  BookLent event is fired into RabbitMQ.3.  The Reminder Service listens for it, and with Hangfire, schedules a reminder email 3 days before the book is due.4. The actual email? That’s handled cleanly by the Notification Service, keeping responsibilities separate.What's Next?I'm diving into some refactoring, but not just any refactoring.I'll be implementing the Outbox Pattern for:- User Registration Emails- Lending Reminder EmailsWhy? Because I want guaranteed delivery.With the Outbox Pattern, events are stored in the same transaction as the main data. Then a background worker reliably publishes them to RabbitMQ.GitHub Repo: https://lnkd.in/dMmSNCWNPrevious Post: https://lnkd.in/dHHkeqJj hashtag#csharp hashtag#dotnet hashtag#microservices hashtag#massTransit hashtag#Hangfire hashtag#outboxpattern hashtag#distributedSystems hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#backenddevelopment hashtag#hiring

🧵Part 8 of my microservices project(BookLending System)Just wrapped up the Reminder Service in my Book Lending microservices project.It listens for a BookLent event, and schedules an email reminder 3 days before the due date using Hangfire. No missed deadlines. No angry librarians. 📚🔔 How it works:1.  When a book is lent (via the Lending Service),2.  BookLent event is fired into RabbitMQ.3.  The Reminder Service listens for it, and with Hangfire, schedules a reminder email 3 days before the book is due.4. The actual email? That’s handled cleanly by the Notification Service, keeping responsibilities separate.What's Next?I'm diving into some refactoring, but not just any refactoring.I'll be implementing the Outbox Pattern for:- User Registration Emails- Lending Reminder EmailsWhy? Because I want guaranteed delivery.With the Outbox Pattern, events are stored in the same transaction as the main data. Then a background worker reliably publishes them to RabbitMQ.GitHub Repo: https://lnkd.in/dMmSNCWNPrevious Post: https://lnkd.in/dHHkeqJj hashtag#csharp hashtag#dotnet hashtag#microservices hashtag#massTransit hashtag#Hangfire hashtag#outboxpattern hashtag#distributedSystems hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#backenddevelopment hashtag#hiring

🧵Part 8 of my microservices project(BookLending System)Just wrapped up the Reminder Service in my Book Lending microservices project.It listens for a BookLent event, and schedules an email reminder 3 days before the due date using Hangfire. No missed deadlines. No angry librarians. 📚🔔 How it works:1.  When a book is lent (via the Lending Service),2.  BookLent event is fired into RabbitMQ.3.  The Reminder Service listens for it, and with Hangfire, schedules a reminder email 3 days before the book is due.4. The actual email? That’s handled cleanly by the Notification Service, keeping responsibilities separate.What's Next?I'm diving into some refactoring, but not just any refactoring.I'll be implementing the Outbox Pattern for:- User Registration Emails- Lending Reminder EmailsWhy? Because I want guaranteed delivery.With the Outbox Pattern, events are stored in the same transaction as the main data. Then a background worker reliably publishes them to RabbitMQ.GitHub Repo: https://lnkd.in/dMmSNCWNPrevious Post: https://lnkd.in/dHHkeqJj hashtag#csharp hashtag#dotnet hashtag#microservices hashtag#massTransit hashtag#Hangfire hashtag#outboxpattern hashtag#distributedSystems hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#backenddevelopment hashtag#hiring

🧵Part 8 of my microservices project(BookLending System)Just wrapped up the Reminder Service in my Book Lending microservices project.It listens for a BookLent event, and schedules an email reminder 3 days before the due date using Hangfire. No missed deadlines. No angry librarians. 📚🔔 How it works:1.  When a book is lent (via the Lending Service),2.  BookLent event is fired into RabbitMQ.3.  The Reminder Service listens for it, and with Hangfire, schedules a reminder email 3 days before the book is due.4. The actual email? That’s handled cleanly by the Notification Service, keeping responsibilities separate.What's Next?I'm diving into some refactoring, but not just any refactoring.I'll be implementing the Outbox Pattern for:- User Registration Emails- Lending Reminder EmailsWhy? Because I want guaranteed delivery.With the Outbox Pattern, events are stored in the same transaction as the main data. Then a background worker reliably publishes them to RabbitMQ.GitHub Repo: https://lnkd.in/dMmSNCWNPrevious Post: https://lnkd.in/dHHkeqJj hashtag#csharp hashtag#dotnet hashtag#microservices hashtag#massTransit hashtag#Hangfire hashtag#outboxpattern hashtag#distributedSystems hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#backenddevelopment hashtag#hiring

🧵Part 8 of my microservices project(BookLending System)Just wrapped up the Reminder Service in my Book Lending microservices project.It listens for a BookLent event, and schedules an email reminder 3 days before the due date using Hangfire. No missed deadlines. No angry librarians. 📚🔔 How it works:1.  When a book is lent (via the Lending Service),2.  BookLent event is fired into RabbitMQ.3.  The Reminder Service listens for it, and with Hangfire, schedules a reminder email 3 days before the book is due.4. The actual email? That’s handled cleanly by the Notification Service, keeping responsibilities separate.What's Next?I'm diving into some refactoring, but not just any refactoring.I'll be implementing the Outbox Pattern for:- User Registration Emails- Lending Reminder EmailsWhy? Because I want guaranteed delivery.With the Outbox Pattern, events are stored in the same transaction as the main data. Then a background worker reliably publishes them to RabbitMQ.GitHub Repo: https://lnkd.in/dMmSNCWNPrevious Post: https://lnkd.in/dHHkeqJj hashtag#csharp hashtag#dotnet hashtag#microservices hashtag#massTransit hashtag#Hangfire hashtag#outboxpattern hashtag#distributedSystems hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#backenddevelopment hashtag#hiring

🧵Part 8 of my microservices project(BookLending System)Just wrapped up the Reminder Service in my Book Lending microservices project.It listens for a BookLent event, and schedules an email reminder 3 days before the due date using Hangfire. No missed deadlines. No angry librarians. 📚🔔 How it works:1.  When a book is lent (via the Lending Service),2.  BookLent event is fired into RabbitMQ.3.  The Reminder Service listens for it, and with Hangfire, schedules a reminder email 3 days before the book is due.4. The actual email? That’s handled cleanly by the Notification Service, keeping responsibilities separate.What's Next?I'm diving into some refactoring, but not just any refactoring.I'll be implementing the Outbox Pattern for:- User Registration Emails- Lending Reminder EmailsWhy? Because I want guaranteed delivery.With the Outbox Pattern, events are stored in the same transaction as the main data. Then a background worker reliably publishes them to RabbitMQ.GitHub Repo: https://lnkd.in/dMmSNCWNPrevious Post: https://lnkd.in/dHHkeqJj hashtag#csharp hashtag#dotnet hashtag#microservices hashtag#massTransit hashtag#Hangfire hashtag#outboxpattern hashtag#distributedSystems hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#backenddevelopment hashtag#hiring

🧵Part 8 of my microservices project(BookLending System)Just wrapped up the Reminder Service in my Book Lending microservices project.It listens for a BookLent event, and schedules an email reminder 3 days before the due date using Hangfire. No missed deadlines. No angry librarians. 📚🔔 How it works:1.  When a book is lent (via the Lending Service),2.  BookLent event is fired into RabbitMQ.3.  The Reminder Service listens for it, and with Hangfire, schedules a reminder email 3 days before the book is due.4. The actual email? That’s handled cleanly by the Notification Service, keeping responsibilities separate.What's Next?I'm diving into some refactoring, but not just any refactoring.I'll be implementing the Outbox Pattern for:- User Registration Emails- Lending Reminder EmailsWhy? Because I want guaranteed delivery.With the Outbox Pattern, events are stored in the same transaction as the main data. Then a background worker reliably publishes them to RabbitMQ.GitHub Repo: https://lnkd.in/dMmSNCWNPrevious Post: https://lnkd.in/dHHkeqJj hashtag#csharp hashtag#dotnet hashtag#microservices hashtag#massTransit hashtag#Hangfire hashtag#outboxpattern hashtag#distributedSystems hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#backenddevelopment hashtag#hiring

🧵Part 8 of my microservices project(BookLending System)Just wrapped up the Reminder Service in my Book Lending microservices project.It listens for a BookLent event, and schedules an email reminder 3 days before the due date using Hangfire. No missed deadlines. No angry librarians. 📚🔔 How it works:1.  When a book is lent (via the Lending Service),2.  BookLent event is fired into RabbitMQ.3.  The Reminder Service listens for it, and with Hangfire, schedules a reminder email 3 days before the book is due.4. The actual email? That’s handled cleanly by the Notification Service, keeping responsibilities separate.What's Next?I'm diving into some refactoring, but not just any refactoring.I'll be implementing the Outbox Pattern for:- User Registration Emails- Lending Reminder EmailsWhy? Because I want guaranteed delivery.With the Outbox Pattern, events are stored in the same transaction as the main data. Then a background worker reliably publishes them to RabbitMQ.GitHub Repo: https://lnkd.in/dMmSNCWNPrevious Post: https://lnkd.in/dHHkeqJj hashtag#csharp hashtag#dotnet hashtag#microservices hashtag#massTransit hashtag#Hangfire hashtag#outboxpattern hashtag#distributedSystems hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#backenddevelopment hashtag#hiring

🧵Part 8 of my microservices project(BookLending System)Just wrapped up the Reminder Service in my Book Lending microservices project.It listens for a BookLent event, and schedules an email reminder 3 days before the due date using Hangfire. No missed deadlines. No angry librarians. 📚🔔 How it works:1.  When a book is lent (via the Lending Service),2.  BookLent event is fired into RabbitMQ.3.  The Reminder Service listens for it, and with Hangfire, schedules a reminder email 3 days before the book is due.4. The actual email? That’s handled cleanly by the Notification Service, keeping responsibilities separate.What's Next?I'm diving into some refactoring, but not just any refactoring.I'll be implementing the Outbox Pattern for:- User Registration Emails- Lending Reminder EmailsWhy? Because I want guaranteed delivery.With the Outbox Pattern, events are stored in the same transaction as the main data. Then a background worker reliably publishes them to RabbitMQ.GitHub Repo: https://lnkd.in/dMmSNCWNPrevious Post: https://lnkd.in/dHHkeqJj hashtag#csharp hashtag#dotnet hashtag#microservices hashtag#massTransit hashtag#Hangfire hashtag#outboxpattern hashtag#distributedSystems hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#backenddevelopment hashtag#hiring

🧵Part 8 of my microservices project(BookLending System)Just wrapped up the Reminder Service in my Book Lending microservices project.It listens for a BookLent event, and schedules an email reminder 3 days before the due date using Hangfire. No missed deadlines. No angry librarians. 📚🔔 How it works:1.  When a book is lent (via the Lending Service),2.  BookLent event is fired into RabbitMQ.3.  The Reminder Service listens for it, and with Hangfire, schedules a reminder email 3 days before the book is due.4. The actual email? That’s handled cleanly by the Notification Service, keeping responsibilities separate.What's Next?I'm diving into some refactoring, but not just any refactoring.I'll be implementing the Outbox Pattern for:- User Registration Emails- Lending Reminder EmailsWhy? Because I want guaranteed delivery.With the Outbox Pattern, events are stored in the same transaction as the main data. Then a background worker reliably publishes them to RabbitMQ.GitHub Repo: https://lnkd.in/dMmSNCWNPrevious Post: https://lnkd.in/dHHkeqJj hashtag#csharp hashtag#dotnet hashtag#microservices hashtag#massTransit hashtag#Hangfire hashtag#outboxpattern hashtag#distributedSystems hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#backenddevelopment hashtag#hiring

🧵Part 8 of my microservices project(BookLending System)Just wrapped up the Reminder Service in my Book Lending microservices project.It listens for a BookLent event, and schedules an email reminder 3 days before the due date using Hangfire. No missed deadlines. No angry librarians. 📚🔔 How it works:1.  When a book is lent (via the Lending Service),2.  BookLent event is fired into RabbitMQ.3.  The Reminder Service listens for it, and with Hangfire, schedules a reminder email 3 days before the book is due.4. The actual email? That’s handled cleanly by the Notification Service, keeping responsibilities separate.What's Next?I'm diving into some refactoring, but not just any refactoring.I'll be implementing the Outbox Pattern for:- User Registration Emails- Lending Reminder EmailsWhy? Because I want guaranteed delivery.With the Outbox Pattern, events are stored in the same transaction as the main data. Then a background worker reliably publishes them to RabbitMQ.GitHub Repo: https://lnkd.in/dMmSNCWNPrevious Post: https://lnkd.in/dHHkeqJj hashtag#csharp hashtag#dotnet hashtag#microservices hashtag#massTransit hashtag#Hangfire hashtag#outboxpattern hashtag#distributedSystems hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#backenddevelopment hashtag#hiring

🧵Part 8 of my microservices project(BookLending System)Just wrapped up the Reminder Service in my Book Lending microservices project.It listens for a BookLent event, and schedules an email reminder 3 days before the due date using Hangfire. No missed deadlines. No angry librarians. 📚🔔 How it works:1.  When a book is lent (via the Lending Service),2.  BookLent event is fired into RabbitMQ.3.  The Reminder Service listens for it, and with Hangfire, schedules a reminder email 3 days before the book is due.4. The actual email? That’s handled cleanly by the Notification Service, keeping responsibilities separate.What's Next?I'm diving into some refactoring, but not just any refactoring.I'll be implementing the Outbox Pattern for:- User Registration Emails- Lending Reminder EmailsWhy? Because I want guaranteed delivery.With the Outbox Pattern, events are stored in the same transaction as the main data. Then a background worker reliably publishes them to RabbitMQ.GitHub Repo: https://lnkd.in/dMmSNCWNPrevious Post: https://lnkd.in/dHHkeqJj hashtag#csharp hashtag#dotnet hashtag#microservices hashtag#massTransit hashtag#Hangfire hashtag#outboxpattern hashtag#distributedSystems hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#backenddevelopment hashtag#hiring

🧵Part 8 of my microservices project(BookLending System)Just wrapped up the Reminder Service in my Book Lending microservices project.It listens for a BookLent event, and schedules an email reminder 3 days before the due date using Hangfire. No missed deadlines. No angry librarians. 📚🔔 How it works:1.  When a book is lent (via the Lending Service),2.  BookLent event is fired into RabbitMQ.3.  The Reminder Service listens for it, and with Hangfire, schedules a reminder email 3 days before the book is due.4. The actual email? That’s handled cleanly by the Notification Service, keeping responsibilities separate.What's Next?I'm diving into some refactoring, but not just any refactoring.I'll be implementing the Outbox Pattern for:- User Registration Emails- Lending Reminder EmailsWhy? Because I want guaranteed delivery.With the Outbox Pattern, events are stored in the same transaction as the main data. Then a background worker reliably publishes them to RabbitMQ.GitHub Repo: https://lnkd.in/dMmSNCWNPrevious Post: https://lnkd.in/dHHkeqJj hashtag#csharp hashtag#dotnet hashtag#microservices hashtag#massTransit hashtag#Hangfire hashtag#outboxpattern hashtag#distributedSystems hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#backenddevelopment hashtag#hiring

Front-End/Full-Stack C# Mobile Developer (Part Time / Full time)Location: Remote — Dallas–Fort Worth metro preferred (flexible)Commitment: Immediate start • Part‑Time with path to Full‑TimeCompensation: Milestone‑based payments plus equity that vests after a waiting periodTRANSPARENCY NOTE• Payment – For each agreed milestone (e.g., “Deliver Feature X”) we jointly define deliverables, target hours, delivery date, and a fixed payment amount. Payment is released as soon as the milestone is accepted.• Equity – You will receive a founding‑engineer equity grant (combination of tokens and company shares) that vests according to a standard cliff and schedule. Equity becomes yours only after the vesting period.If an outcome‑based, ownership‑heavy model excites you, read on.WHAT YOU’LL DO• Own the MVP mobile app end‑to‑end: architecture, coding, testing, deployment, and iteration.• Implement UI/UX designs provided by our designer through Figma.• Ship fast in .NET 8/9 C# using MAUI Hybrid, Blazor, and WebAssembly for a single codebase across mobile and web.• Drive frontend excellence—pixel‑perfect, intuitive, performant experiences are priority #1.• Contribute to lightweight backend APIs (auth, data models, CI/CD hooks) when needed.• Set up the pipeline: automated builds, test harnesses, and App Store / Play Store releases.• Influence product direction directly with the founders—your voice matters.• Help establish engineering best practices: coding standards, code review culture, branching strategy, and a “you build it, you own it” ops mindset.MUST‑HAVE SKILLS & EXPERIENCE• .NET 8/9 and C# — expert, production‑grade code• MAUI Hybrid & Blazor (WASM) — built at least one cross‑platform mobile app through launch• Modern frontend craft — responsive UI, accessibility, offline‑first patterns• RESTful APIs & JSON — consumption and lightweight authoring• Source control with Git/GitHub — branch strategy, pull‑request reviews, actions/workflows• Startup execution — comfort with ambiguity, bias toward action, radical ownershipNICE‑TO‑HAVE EXTRAS• Azure serverless, especially AKS and Key Vault• Figma‑based UI/UX implementation experience• Containers & orchestration: Docker, Kubernetes/AKS, Helm charts• MongoDB schema design and tuning• Automated testing with xUnit• CI/CD using GitHub Actions or Azure PipelinesREADY TO BUILD SOMETHING THAT MATTERS?Email careers@newbitcoin.app with:• Resume or/and a brief note on why our stack and mission excite you.• Links to apps you shipped (GitHub or store listings).We respect your time: please apply only if a milestone‑based payments model plus later‑vesting equity fits your situation. We move fast—expect a quick technical chat, a take‑home mini task (a couple of hours max), and a founder call to discuss milestones, pay, equity, and next steps.hashtag#dotnet hashtag#blazor hashtag#maui hashtag#web3 hashtag#crypto hashtag#JobOpening

🧵Part 8 of my microservices project(BookLending System)Just wrapped up the Reminder Service in my Book Lending microservices project.It listens for a BookLent event, and schedules an email reminder 3 days before the due date using Hangfire. No missed deadlines. No angry librarians. 📚🔔 How it works:1.  When a book is lent (via the Lending Service),2.  BookLent event is fired into RabbitMQ.3.  The Reminder Service listens for it, and with Hangfire, schedules a reminder email 3 days before the book is due.4. The actual email? That’s handled cleanly by the Notification Service, keeping responsibilities separate.What's Next?I'm diving into some refactoring, but not just any refactoring.I'll be implementing the Outbox Pattern for:- User Registration Emails- Lending Reminder EmailsWhy? Because I want guaranteed delivery.With the Outbox Pattern, events are stored in the same transaction as the main data. Then a background worker reliably publishes them to RabbitMQ.GitHub Repo: https://lnkd.in/dMmSNCWNPrevious Post: https://lnkd.in/dHHkeqJj hashtag#csharp hashtag#dotnet hashtag#microservices hashtag#massTransit hashtag#Hangfire hashtag#outboxpattern hashtag#distributedSystems hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#backenddevelopment hashtag#hiring

🧵Part 8 of my microservices project(BookLending System)Just wrapped up the Reminder Service in my Book Lending microservices project.It listens for a BookLent event, and schedules an email reminder 3 days before the due date using Hangfire. No missed deadlines. No angry librarians. 📚🔔 How it works:1.  When a book is lent (via the Lending Service),2.  BookLent event is fired into RabbitMQ.3.  The Reminder Service listens for it, and with Hangfire, schedules a reminder email 3 days before the book is due.4. The actual email? That’s handled cleanly by the Notification Service, keeping responsibilities separate.What's Next?I'm diving into some refactoring, but not just any refactoring.I'll be implementing the Outbox Pattern for:- User Registration Emails- Lending Reminder EmailsWhy? Because I want guaranteed delivery.With the Outbox Pattern, events are stored in the same transaction as the main data. Then a background worker reliably publishes them to RabbitMQ.GitHub Repo: https://lnkd.in/dMmSNCWNPrevious Post: https://lnkd.in/dHHkeqJj hashtag#csharp hashtag#dotnet hashtag#microservices hashtag#massTransit hashtag#Hangfire hashtag#outboxpattern hashtag#distributedSystems hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#backenddevelopment hashtag#hiring

🧵Part 8 of my microservices project(BookLending System)Just wrapped up the Reminder Service in my Book Lending microservices project.It listens for a BookLent event, and schedules an email reminder 3 days before the due date using Hangfire. No missed deadlines. No angry librarians. 📚🔔 How it works:1.  When a book is lent (via the Lending Service),2.  BookLent event is fired into RabbitMQ.3.  The Reminder Service listens for it, and with Hangfire, schedules a reminder email 3 days before the book is due.4. The actual email? That’s handled cleanly by the Notification Service, keeping responsibilities separate.What's Next?I'm diving into some refactoring, but not just any refactoring.I'll be implementing the Outbox Pattern for:- User Registration Emails- Lending Reminder EmailsWhy? Because I want guaranteed delivery.With the Outbox Pattern, events are stored in the same transaction as the main data. Then a background worker reliably publishes them to RabbitMQ.GitHub Repo: https://lnkd.in/dMmSNCWNPrevious Post: https://lnkd.in/dHHkeqJj hashtag#csharp hashtag#dotnet hashtag#microservices hashtag#massTransit hashtag#Hangfire hashtag#outboxpattern hashtag#distributedSystems hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#backenddevelopment hashtag#hiring

🧵Part 8 of my microservices project(BookLending System)Just wrapped up the Reminder Service in my Book Lending microservices project.It listens for a BookLent event, and schedules an email reminder 3 days before the due date using Hangfire. No missed deadlines. No angry librarians. 📚🔔 How it works:1.  When a book is lent (via the Lending Service),2.  BookLent event is fired into RabbitMQ.3.  The Reminder Service listens for it, and with Hangfire, schedules a reminder email 3 days before the book is due.4. The actual email? That’s handled cleanly by the Notification Service, keeping responsibilities separate.What's Next?I'm diving into some refactoring, but not just any refactoring.I'll be implementing the Outbox Pattern for:- User Registration Emails- Lending Reminder EmailsWhy? Because I want guaranteed delivery.With the Outbox Pattern, events are stored in the same transaction as the main data. Then a background worker reliably publishes them to RabbitMQ.GitHub Repo: https://lnkd.in/dMmSNCWNPrevious Post: https://lnkd.in/dHHkeqJj hashtag#csharp hashtag#dotnet hashtag#microservices hashtag#massTransit hashtag#Hangfire hashtag#outboxpattern hashtag#distributedSystems hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#backenddevelopment hashtag#hiring
